Description: Shoulder and body sherd of Clazomenian black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly a neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure dancing female figure to left (part of upper body and waist, left arm in added white from shoulder to wrist and sleeve to elbow depicted with four white rectangles probably indicating flesh showing through).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

For a parallel regarding the type of sleeve, see Cook, R. M. and Dupont, P., East Greek Pottery. London 1998, 97, fig. 12.2. Cook identifies this sherd as being amongst the earliest examples of vases from his Tübingen Group.
Bibliographic references: Cook 1952 / A List of Clazomenian Pottery (p. 124, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GH.020) (Phase 1)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
